Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates reclining on the back of a goose; he wears a himation, extending from his left shoulder and covering him from the waist down, leaving his legs free below the knees. A Double Crown surmounts his hair, and lappets of a ribbon emerge from behind his head to fall on his shoulders. His finger is to his mouth and he holds a cornucopia in the crook of his left arm. The goose stands stolidly, with its foot on a flat-faced plinth. Back plain, except for a raised rim round a circular vent. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface. Traces of an overall white dressing.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Ptolemaic or Roman, first century BC/AD. Comparanda: Close: Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no. 136, dated first century AD; Christie's 'Sale Catalogue', 13 July 1983: lot 331; Dunand 1990: nos 187 and 188, the last with an alien head (?), dated Roman period; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 27; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 35:14; Skupinska-Løvset 1978: no. UT 128, dated second part of the second century BC; Weber 1914: no. 100, with modern inscription. Near: Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no. 135, dated first century AD; Dunand 1990: no. 190, dated Roman period. Not unlike: Besques 1992: no. E 360, perhaps from Antinoopolis, dated Roman period. Bibliog: Gutch 1898–9: 93; Budge 1925: pl. xxviii; Fischer 1994: 277, no. 616.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3074)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
